_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.



The management and employees of Conserv FS, Inc. are committed to the prevention of

any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur,

the facility is prepared to work with the Boone County Fire District #2, Boone County Local Emergency Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2.The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.



The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 7559 Dewane Road, is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of one 30000 gallon storage tank, nurse tanks, loading risers and associated plumbing.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 



3.  The accidental release prevention program.



This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration(osha), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.



4.  Five year accident history.



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:



-   have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or



-   to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter

in

    place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5.  The emergency response program.



      The facility has:



-  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR     1910.38;



-  provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-    know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



- In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify  the Boone County Fire District #2 and Boone County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.



6.  Planned changes to improve safety.



     Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
